facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 174 of 1952 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 174 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Decree dated 27th June 1950 of High Court of Patiala and East Punjab States Union in Second Appeal No. 219 of 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 27th June, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature of Patiala and East Punjab States Union in Second Appeal No. 219 of 1949-50

facts.text: Judgment and Decree dated 21st September 1949 of Additional District Judge Bhatinda in Appeal No. 61 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: against the Judgment and Decree dated the 21st September, 1949, of the Court of the Additional District Judge, Bhatinda, in Appeal No. 61 of 1948,

facts.text: Judgment and Decree dated 10th August 1948 of Sub-Judge 1st Class Mansa in Case No. 134 of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: arising from the Judgment and Decree dated the 10th August, 1948, of the Court of the Sub-Judge 1st Class, Mansa, in Case No. 134 of 1947.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by BOSE J. on April 2 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Gopal Singh and Sardar Singh for the appellants. Achhru Ram  K. L. Mehta, with him  for the respondent. 1954. April 2.

facts.text: Plaintiffs are presumptive reversioners to Harnam Singh who owned the property in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs appeal. They claim to be the presumptive reversioners to one Harnam Singh who owned the property in dispute.

facts.text: Harnam Singh died before 2nd November 1914.

anchor.surface_text: On 2nd November, 1914, after Harnam Singhs death, his daughter Mst. Biro, the second defendant,

facts.text: On 2nd November 1914, Mst. Biro gifted plaint properties to her sons grouped as first defendant.

anchor.surface_text: On 2nd November, 1914, after Harnam Singhs death, his daughter Mst. Biro, the second defendant, gifted the plaint properties to her sons who have been grouped together as the first defendant.

facts.text: Plaintiffs contend property is ancestral and daughter got only life estate.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs contend that the property is ancestral and that the daughter got only a life estate, so they sue for a declaration that the gift will not affect their reversionary rights.

facts.text: Defendants state according to customary law collaterals beyond fifth degree are not heirs in presence of daughter and her line; plaintiffs are seventh degree.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants rely on custom. They state that, according to the customary law which governs the parties, collaterals beyond the fifth degree are not heirs in the presence of a daughter and her line.

facts.text: Defendants state property was not ancestral.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs, they say, are collaterals of the seventh degree therefore they cannot displace the daughter. They also state that the property was not ancestral

facts.text: Harnam Singh gifted 123 bighas of Khas land to second defendant absolutely.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants say that Harnam Singh gifted 123 bighas of the Khas land to the second defendant that the gift was absolute and so the plaintiffs cannot get that portion

facts.text: Property in suit consisted of 253 bighas of Khas land, half share in 3 bighas 19 biswas, share in shamlat property.

anchor.surface_text: The third line of defence related to a portion of the property which is not in dispute before us. The property in suit consisted of three items  1  253 bighas of Khas land  2  a half share in 3 bighas 19 biswas and  3  a share in certain shamlat property.

facts.text: Trial Judge held on admission of plaintiffs counsel that land was not ancestral and daughters sons succeed after her to exclusion of plaintiffs; gift acceleration; dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge held, on the admission of the plaintiffs counsel, that the land in dispute was not-ancestral and that the daughters sons would succeed after her to the exclusion of the plaintiffs, therefore the gift by her to her sons amounted to an acceleration of the estate. The learned Judge dismissed the plaintiffs Suit,

facts.text: Lower appellate court upheld not-ancestral as conceded; house not included in gift so no acceleration; decreed plaintiffs claim.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the lower appellate Court- the finding ,that the property was not-ancestral was upheld as the plaintiffs learned counsel in that Court did not contest the finding of the first Court on this point. As regards the acceleration, the learned Judge thought it necessary to examine a point which the plaintiffs had raised in the trial Court but which was ignored there, namely that a house was not included in the gift.

facts.text: High Court upheld not-ancestral conceded; house not included but small, does not prevent acceleration; reversed lower appellate, restored trial decree.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court the learned Judges upheld the concurrent finding about the not-ancestral nature of the property. Before them also the point was conceded by the plaintiffs counsel. They also held that the house was not included in the gift but held that it was such a small part of the estate that the daughters retention of it could not indicate an intention on her part not to efface herself from the estate.

facts.text: Supreme Court did not allow reopening not-ancestral finding as conceded in three courts and res judicata from previous suits.

anchor.surface_text: Before us, the plaintiffs learned counsel tried to reopen the concurrent finding of the three Courts about the not- ancestral nature of the property but we did not allow him to do so. The question is a mixed question of law and fact and the admission involved both.

facts.text: Harnam Singh mortgaged part of estate, placed mortgagees in possession; collaterals took unencumbered portion; Mst. Biro sued for possession and declaration, succeeded on not-ancestral ground.

anchor.surface_text: Harnam Singh had mortgaged a part of his estate and placed the mortgagees in possession. When he died some of his collaterals took possession of the unencumbered portion of the estate. The daughter Mst. Biro therefore instituted two suits, one for possession against the collaterals including the present plaintiffs or their predecessors, and the other for a declaration against the mortgagees in possession.

facts.text: Previous judgments Exhibits DD and DF held property not-ancestral, res judicata.

anchor.surface_text: These findings are obviously res-judicata and if the plaintiffs learned counsel had not conceded the point the question would at once have been raised and the previous judgments, which were exhibited  Exhibits DD and DF  would-have concluded the matter.

facts.text: Property in dispute was not-ancestral.

anchor.surface_text: It, must therefore be accepted here that the whole of the land in dispute was not-ancestral.

facts.text: High Court held plaintiffs collaterals in fifth degree not seventh.

anchor.surface_text: They also held in the plaintiffs favour that they were collaterals in the fifth degree and not the seventh

facts.text: Gift extent over 253 bighas; absolute gift of 123 bighas by Harnam; house retained very small part.

anchor.surface_text: The extent of the property covered by the gift is over 253 bighas. She had an absolute right to gift 123 bighas of this

facts.text: House description: tiny dwelling, distance two karams, lives Mst. Biro and three sons.

anchor.surface_text: Garja Singh  P.W. 1  gives us this description of it The distance between the door of the Sabbat and that of Darwaja is only about two karams.  eleven feet . opposite to Darwaja there is one Jhallani

facts.text: Court held gift operated as acceleration despite house retention.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that the gift operated accelerate the succession.

These findings are obviously res-judicata and if the plaintiffs learned counsel had not conceded the point the question would at once have been raised and the previous judgments, which were exhibited  Exhibits DD and DF  would-have concluded the matter.

concepts.interpretation: Previous judgments (Exhibits DD and DF) holding the property as non-ancestral in suits between the same parties or predecessors are res judicata and would conclude the matter if not conceded.

concepts.interpretation: Under Punjab customary law for agricultural Jats (per Rattigan's Digest para 23(2)), daughter is preferred to collaterals in succession to father's acquired (non-ancestral) property.

concepts.unlisted_label: Daughter's Preference to Collaterals in Acquired Property
concepts.unlisted_description: Customary rule preferring daughter over collaterals for father's self-acquired property.

anchor.surface_text: but what the plaintiffs contend is that she only succeeds as a limited heir and that after her the reversion will go to the fathers heirs in the usual way. But that is not the Punjab custom among the tribe to which the parties belong, namely agricultural Jats. Rattigan quotes the following passage from page 61 of Roe and Rattigans Tribal -Law-of the Punjab at page 411 of the 13th edition of his Digest Where a succession of a married daughter is allowed, the general principle is that she succeeds not as an ordinary heir,, but merely as the means of passing on the property to another male, whose descent from her father in the female line is allowed under exceptional circumstances to count as if it were descent in the male line.

concepts.interpretation: Under Punjab Jat custom (Roe & Rattigan, Rattigan Digest), married daughter succeeds to father's property not as absolute heir but limited like widow, to pass to her male issue; on failure, reverts to father's agnates.

concepts.unlisted_label: Limited Estate of Daughter under Custom
concepts.unlisted_description: Daughter holds as life estate holder passing property to sons under male-line equivalent succession.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the plaintiffs relies on, paragraph 64 of Rattigans Digest where it is stated that except in two cases which do -not apply here, no female in possession of property from, among others, her father can permanently alienate it.

concepts.interpretation: Per Rattigan para 64, limited female heir cannot permanently alienate, but distinguished here as the gift is not treated as alienation but potential acceleration.

concepts.unlisted_label: No Permanent Alienation by Limited Female Heir
concepts.unlisted_description: Customary prohibition on permanent alienation by daughter in possession from father.

anchor.surface_text: the only portion to which the doctrine of surrender would apply would be the remaining 130 odd bighas. But the fact that she gave away all her property to her sons, bar this house, including property to which she had an absolute right, is relevant to show that her intention was to efface herself completely. ... The law about this has been correctly set out in Mullas Hindu Law, 11th edition, page 217, in the following terms But the omission, due to ignorance or to oversight,, of a small portion of the whole property does not affect the validity of the surrender when it is otherwise bona fide.

concepts.interpretation: Retention of tiny house (small portion) does not invalidate surrender/acceleration by daughter to sons, per Mulla's Hindu Law rule on bona fide surrender omitting small portion.

anchor.surface_text: Before us, the plaintiffs learned counsel tried to reopen the concurrent finding of the three Courts about the not- ancestral nature of the property but we did not allow him to do so. ... We agree with the High Court that the gift operated accelerate the succession. That being the case, the plaintiffs are no longer the reversions even if they would otherwise have been entitled to succeed on failure of the daughters sons and their line

concepts.interpretation: Gift by daughter (limited heir under custom) to her sons accelerates their succession, vesting estate in them and excluding collaterals/reversioners.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: h of sons and their attaining majority, for her own life but she has numbermore power over it than a widow would have. If she has sons, the estate wil

issues.text: Whether the property in dispute was ancestral or non-ancestral

anchor.surface_text: Before us, the plaintiffs learned counsel tried to reopen the concurrent finding of the three Courts about the not- ancestral nature of the property but we did not allow him to do so. The question is a mixed question of law and fact and the admission involved both. We were not shown how the facts admitted could be disentangled from the law so that we could determine whether the conclusion of law drawn from the admitted facts was wrong.

issues.text: What is the question of heirship under Punjab custom for agricultural Jats regarding succession to father's acquired property by daughter and collaterals

anchor.surface_text: These findings are obviously res-judicata and if the plaintiffs learned counsel had not conceded the point the question would at once have been raised and the previous judgments, which were exhibited  Exhibits DD and DF  would-have concluded the matter. But as the point was conceded in all three Courts it was not necessary for the defendants to fall back on the previous decisions. It, must therefore be accepted here that the whole of the land in dispute was non-ancestral. That brings us to the question of heirship.

issues.text: Whether the gift by the daughter to her sons constitutes an alienation or an acceleration of the estate

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 23 2  of Rattigans Digest of Customary Law says that- In regard to the acquired property of her father, the daughter is preferred to the collaterals. That is not disputed but what the plaintiffs contend is that she only succeeds as a limited heir and that after her the reversion will go to the fathers heirs in the usual way. But that is not the Punjab custom among the tribe to which the parties belong, namely agricultural Jats.

issues.text: Whether the retention by Mst. Biro of the house would prevent an acceleration of the estate under the doctrine of surrender

anchor.surface_text: the only portion to which the doctrine of surrender would apply would be the remaining 130 odd bighas. But the fact that she gave away all her property to her sons, bar this house, including property to which she had an absolute right, is relevant to show that her intention was to efface herself completely. ... The law about this has been correctly set out in Mullas Hindu Law, 11th edition, page 217, in the following terms But the omission, due to ignorance or to oversight,, of a small portion of the whole property does not affect the validity of the surrender when it is otherwise bona fide.

issues.text: Whether the plaintiffs as collaterals in the fifth degree would be heirs at all

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that the gift operated accelerate the succession. That being the case, the plaintiffs are no longer the reversions even if they would otherwise have been entitled to succeed on failure of the daughters sons and their line We need not decide whether the plaintiffs, as collaterals in the fifth degree, would be heirs at all.

holdings.text: The property in dispute was non-ancestral and the concurrent finding of the lower courts on this point cannot be reopened.

anchor.surface_text: Before us, the plaintiffs learned counsel tried to reopen the concurrent finding of the three Courts about the not- ancestral nature of the property but we did not allow him to do so. The question is a mixed question of law and fact and the admission involved both.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conceded in all lower courts; mixed question of law and fact; res judicata from previous judgments (Exhibits DD and DF).

holdings.text: It must therefore be accepted here that the whole of the land in dispute was non-ancestral.

anchor.surface_text: It, must therefore be accepted here that the whole of the land in dispute was non-ancestral. That brings us to the question of heirship.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiffs conceded in all courts; previous judgments res judicata.

holdings.text: Under Punjab customary law for agricultural Jats, in regard to acquired property of her father, the daughter is preferred to collaterals and succeeds not as ordinary heir but to pass property to her sons as if male line descent.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 23 2  of Rattigans Digest of Customary Law says that- In regard to the acquired property of her father, the daughter is preferred to the collaterals. That is not disputed but what the plaintiffs contend is that she only succeeds as a limited heir

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rattigan Digest para 23(2) and quote from Roe & Rattigan; supported by Punjab cases Lehna v. Mst. Thakri and Lal Singh v. Roor Singh.

holdings.text: The gift to the sons is not an alienation but an acceleration of the estate; para 64 of Rattigan on no permanent alienation by female does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the plaintiffs relies on, paragraph 64 of Rattigans Digest where it is stated that except in two cases which do -not apply here, no female in possession of property from, among others, her father can permanently alienate it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between alienation and acceleration; gift form immaterial if acceleration occurs.

holdings.text: Retention of the tiny house by Mst. Biro does not prevent acceleration of the estate as it is a small portion omitted due to oversight in otherwise bona fide surrender.

anchor.surface_text: The law about this has been correctly set out in Mullas Hindu Law, 11th edition, page 217, in the following terms But the omission, due to ignorance or to oversight,, of a small portion of the whole property does not affect the validity of the surrender when it is otherwise bona fide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: House is minuscule part of 253 bighas; intention to efface completely shown by gifting all else including absolute property; per Mulla's Hindu Law p.217.

holdings.text: The gift operated to accelerate the succession; plaintiffs are no longer reversioners.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court; combines daughter as limited heir passing to sons, acceleration despite minor retention.

holdings.text: No need to decide whether plaintiffs as fifth degree collaterals would be heirs at all.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary as acceleration vests estate in daughter's sons excluding reversioners.

precedents.citation: Lehna v., Mst. Thakri 1 32 Punjab Record 1895

anchor.surface_text: In Lehna v., Mst. Thakri  1  two learned Judges of the Punjab Chief Court  the third dissenting  said in the course of a Full Bench decision, that even in the case of ancestral property the daughters sons and their descendants would exclude companylaterals of the father.

precedents.citation: Lal Singh v. Roor Singh 2 55 Punjab Law Reporter 168 at 172

anchor.surface_text: In a more recent case  1953  the Punjab High Court held in Lal Singh v. Roor Singh  2  that in the case of number-ancestral property the daughters are preferred to companylaterals.

precedents.cited_proposition: in the case of number-ancestral property the daughters are preferred to companylaterals
